Article Title: Starlink, Jio, Airtel face further delay in satellite internet rollout amid TRAI–DoT standoff
Article Text:
DoT proposes to increase spectrum prices





Elon Musk’s Starlink, Jio and Airtel may have to wait longer than expected to launch satellite based internet services in India. According to a report by Economic Times, commercial rollout may take longer because of a standoff between the telecom regulator and the department of telecommunications (DoT) over spectrum pricing. The report quotes industry executives who said that the process could potentially take another 3-6 months amid upcoming personnel changes at the DoT and industry interference.Till date, Starlink, Eutelsat OneWeb and Jio Satellite have completed most of the licensing and space-regulatory steps, including obtaining the Global Mobile Personal Communication by Satellite (GMPCS) licence, and approvals from space-regulatory body In-SPACe.However, commercial launch depends on spectrum allocation, pricing rules and compliance with security and capacity rules.Shivaji Chatterjee, CEO and managing director of Hughes Communications India told the publication: “The current spectrum pricing proposals, including the disagreements between Trai (Telecom Regulatory Authority of India) and DoT regarding LEO (low earth orbit satellite) spectrum pricing must first be reviewed by a standing committee.The proposal then moves to the digital communications commission (DCC) for approval”.Once approved, the matter will go to the telecom minister or union cabinet, he said. After the ministerial approval is granted, the wireless planning and coordination wing (WPC) will create specific rules. These rules will eventually be put out for public consultation for 30 days.“This stage is critical as terrestrial telecom operators may attempt to impede the process during the feedback window,” Chatterjee said.Initially, the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) had proposed a flat rate of 4% of adjusted gross revenues to be charged for spectrum allocation. But the DoT recently proposed to raise charges to 5% of AGR with a 1% discount if they meet specific rural rollout targets.An industry executive said the government’s move to increase spectrum charges from the earlier suggested rate may be meant to calm telecom operators, who have been asking for a level playing field. The person added that raising the fee from 4% to 5% would not make a major financial difference for the government. “It was mainly a symbolic step to show that the DoT was responding to telco concerns,” the executive told ET.
Article Summary: Commercial launch depends on spectrum allocation, pricing rules and compliance with security and capacity rules. Starlink, Eutelsat OneWeb and Jio Satellite have completed most of the licensing and space-regulatory steps, including obtaining the Global Mobile Personal Communication by Satellite (GMPCS) licence.

Article Title: One of Europe’s biggest chipmakers STMicro says it aims to ship 10 billion chips for Starlink by 2027
Article Text:
STMicro chips drive commercial space boom







STMicroelectronics has disclosed the numbers involving the massive scale of its partnership with Elon Musk’s SpaceX . The company said that it has already shipped over 5 billion radio-frequency antenna chips for the Starlink satellite network, and projects that the volume of chips delivered under the contract may potentially double in the next two years.According to a report by news agency Reuters, the statement signals the accelerating growth of the commercial space market and the vitality of specialised chip suppliers. These are crucial components in Starlink user terminals.STMicro's specialised chip business has reaped the benefits of the boom in the commercial space market, which is rapidly shifting away from government-led projects.This is being spearheaded by companies like SpaceX, Eutelsat’s OneWeb and Amazon's planned Project Kuiper (Leo network).“I expect many lower-orbit satellite players to leverage the technology,” El-Ouazzane said while expecting this demand to continue growing as these specialized chips are capable of handling high data rates and designed to survive the harsh conditions of space. STMicro is positioned to supply the upcoming inter-satellite laser links for next-generation SpaceX platforms.

The company projects that the volume of chips delivered under the contract may potentially double in the next two years. The revelation comes a decade after the Tesla CEO first met with STMicroelectronics CEO Jean-Marc Chery.

Article Title: Amazon cuts more jobs in Washington, unrelated to 14000 broader layoffs; here's what notice to State government says
Article Text:
Amazon CEO Andy Jassy on layoffs





Amazon layoffs continue, as the company is cutting more jobs. According to a report in Geekwire, Amazon has filed a new notice with Washington state. As per the filing with the State government, the company is cutting 84 jobs and that these job cuts are unrelated to the 14,000 corporate layoffs it announced globally in October. In a statement to the publication, the company said that each of its businesses regularly reviews its organizational structure and may make adjustments as a result. Terming it a "routine process", the company spokesperson also confirmed that these job cuts are not tied to broader workforce actions.Amazon filed notice with Washinton authourities as a new State law requires companies/employers to disclose all terminations occurring within 90 days of a prior notice under the State’s new version of the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, known as the WARN Act.“We’ve informed a relatively small number of employees that their roles will be eliminated as the result of individual business decisions,” said Amazon spokesperson Brad Glasser. “We don’t make decisions like this lightly,” he added, noting that the company is providing affected employees with 90 days of full pay and benefits, transitional health coverage, and job placement services.What Amazon filing saysAccording to Amazon filing, the separations are scheduled to occur between February 2 and February 23, 2026, across more than 30 Seattle and Bellevue office locations, plus six remote workers based in Washington.They reportedly include software development engineers, program managers, recruiters, HR specialists, and UX designers, ranging from entry-level to directors and principals.Amazon noted in the filing that employees were notified starting in early November and received at least 89 days’ advance notice, exceeding the 60-day minimum required under the law. Those who find internal transfers before their separation date won’t be laid off.In October, Amazon said that it will lay off 2,303 corporate employees in Washington state, primarily in its Seattle and Bellevue offices. The company revealed the same in a filing with the State Employment Security Department. The number provided the first geographic breakdown of the company’s 14,000 global job cuts.A detailed list included with the State filing showed impacted roles, including software engineers, program managers, product managers, and designers, as well as a significant number of recruiters and human resources staff.Amazon announced the cuts on October 27 as part of a larger push by CEO Andy Jassy to streamline the company. Jassy said in June that the increased use of artificial intelligence tools would likely lead to further job cuts, particularly through automating repetitive and routine tasks. In a memo from HR chief Beth Galetti, the company signaled that further cutbacks will continue into 2026.
Article Summary: Amazon has filed a new notice with Washington state. The company is cutting 84 jobs and that these job cuts are unrelated to the 14,000 corporate layoffs it announced globally in October. In October, Amazon said that it will lay off 2,303 corporate employees in Washington state, primarily in its Seattle and Bellevue offices.

Article Title: AI at work: Survey shows which jobs are using AI the most
Article Text:
Knowledge-based jobs lead AI use

AI-Powered Future: Next Gen Careers You Should Watch

Frontline industries lag behind

Managers and leaders use AI more often





Uncertainty about organisational AI strategy

How employees are using AI at work

AI use grows, but daily adoption remains limited





Artificial intelligence is becoming a regular part of working life around the world, but its adoption remains uneven across the labour market. According to the latest Gallup workforce survey, nearly half of American employees now use AI at work at least a few times a year, a figure that continues to rise quarter by quarter. While usage is growing overall, the data show clear differences between industries, job roles, and levels of seniority, revealing where AI has taken hold and where it remains marginal.Employees in knowledge-intensive roles are far more likely to use AI than those in frontline positions. Gallup found that three-quarters of workers in technology or information systems roles reported using AI at least a few times a year. Usage was also high in finance and professional services, where more than half of employees said AI was part of their work. These roles typically involve data analysis, writing, coding or research, areas where AI tools are easiest to integrate.In contrast, AI use remains significantly lower in sectors dominated by frontline work. Only about a third of employees in retail reported using AI at work, while healthcare and manufacturing showed similarly modest adoption.Frontline roles such as shop floor sales assistants, cashiers, warehouse operatives, nurses, healthcare aides, machine operators and assembly-line workers typically rely on physical presence and manual tasks, limiting opportunities to apply digital AI tools in day-to-day duties.The survey highlights a clear gap between senior staff and individual contributors. Leaders and managers are more likely to use AI frequently, often a few times a week or more, compared with frontline employees and junior staff. This reflects both greater access to AI tools and closer involvement in planning, reporting and decision-making tasks where AI can add immediate value.Despite rising usage, many employees remain unclear about whether their organisation has formally adopted AI. Gallup found that a significant share of workers, particularly individual contributors and frontline staff, said they did not know if their employer had implemented AI technology. This suggests that some employees are using personal or unofficial AI tools without clear guidance or awareness of company strategy.Among those who use AI, the most common applications include consolidating information, generating ideas and learning new skills. Chatbots and virtual assistants are the most widely used tools, followed by AI-powered writing and editing software. More advanced tools, such as coding assistants and data analytics platforms, remain relatively rare and are mostly used by employees who rely on AI frequently.While overall AI use continues to expand, daily use is still confined to a small portion of the workforce. Gallup’s findings suggest that broader adoption depends less on access to technology and more on leadership support, clear communication and practical guidance. Without these, AI is likely to remain concentrated in specific jobs rather than becoming a universal workplace tool.
Article Summary: Artificial intelligence is becoming a regular part of working life around the world, but its adoption remains uneven across the labour market. Nearly half of American employees now use AI at work at least a few times a year, a figure that continues to rise quarter by quarter. While usage is growing overall, the data show clear differences between industries, job roles and levels of seniority.

Article Title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang on why despite being the CEO of world's most-valuable company, sense of uncertainty and insecurity doesn't leave him
Article Text:
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang, despite leading his company to a $5 trillion valuation, lives in constant anxiety, a fear rooted in a near-bankruptcy experience. Recent reports of Meta potentially buying Google's AI chips have caused a $250 billion market value drop, validating Huang's long-held belief that the company is always '30 days from going out of business'.

Nvidia Makes History: First Company to Hit $4 Trillion Market Cap

A near-death experience that shaped Huang’s three decades of paranoia

Why Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang 's fears suddenly look prophetic





Despite leading Nvidia to become the first company ever to hit a $5 trillion valuation, CEO Jensen Huang admits he operates in constant anxiety, working every single day including holidays. His fears may be justified—this week alone, Nvidia lost $250 billion in market value after reports emerged that Meta is in advanced talks to buy billions worth of competing chips from Google , threatening the chipmaker's decade-long dominance in AI hardware."The phrase '30 days from going out of business'—I've used for 33 years," Huang revealed on The Joe Rogan Experience podcast. "The feeling doesn't change. The sense of vulnerability, the sense of uncertainty, the sense of insecurity—it doesn't leave you."Huang's anxiety isn't unfounded paranoia—it's scar tissue from survival. In the mid-1990s, Nvidia discovered fatal flaws in its first graphics chip while developing technology for Sega's gaming console. With funds evaporating, Huang flew to Japan for an excruciating conversation: he told Sega's CEO the product wouldn't work and the deal must end, but simultaneously begged for the final $5 million payment to prevent bankruptcy.Remarkably, Sega converted it into an investment, giving Nvidia the lifeline that eventually built a trillion-dollar empire.That near-collapse experience now fuels Huang's relentless schedule. He wakes at 4 a.m. daily to read "several thousand emails," works seven days a week without exception—"including Thanksgiving, Christmas"—and admits he's "always in a state of anxiety." His motivation? "I have a greater drive from not wanting to fail than the drive of wanting to succeed. Failure drives me more than greed."Huang's paranoia might be wisdom. Nvidia made the rare move of issuing a public defense after The Information reported that Meta—planning up to $72 billion in AI spending this year—is negotiating massive purchases of Google's tensor processing units (TPUs). The news triggered a 6% stock plunge, erasing roughly $250 billion in value, while Alphabet shares surged 4%."Nvidia is a generation ahead of the industry—it's the only platform that runs every AI model," the company declared on X, breaking its usual silence on competitors. But Google's latest Gemini 3 AI model, trained entirely on TPUs rather than Nvidia chips, is being hailed by industry leaders as potentially superior. Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff publicly announced he's switching from ChatGPT after three years, calling Gemini 3 the better product.The threat is existential to Nvidia's 90% market share in AI accelerators. If Google captures even a fraction of the hundreds of billions being spent on AI processors—particularly from customers like Meta—it would represent the first serious crack in Nvidia's dominance.Huang's work ethic has infected his family: both his children, Madison and Spencer, now in their thirties, work at Nvidia after joining as interns in 2020 and 2022. "Now we have three people working every day," Huang said.For a CEO who never stopped running scared despite building a $4.5-trillion empire, the market turmoil caused by Google likely only confirmed what he's believed for 33 years: you're always 30 days from going out of business.
Article Summary: Jensen Huang is the CEO of Nvidia, the first company ever to hit a $5 trillion valuation. He wakes at 4 a.m. daily to read "several thousand emails," works seven days a week without exception, including holidays. Recent reports of Meta potentially buying Google's AI chips have caused a $250 billion market value drop, validating Huang's belief that the company is always '30 days from going out of business'

Article Title: E-passport explained: What is it, who can apply, what happens to existing ones and other things to know
Article Text:
What is e-passport

How to apply for e-passport





The Ministry of External Affairs rolled out e-passport service under the Passport Seva Programme (PSP V2.0). With the new system, the government aims to facilitate faster, more secure, and smooth travel for all Indian passport holders. While the existing ones remain valid till their expiry, anyone applying for a passport will get a chip-enabled passport by default, irrespective of whether they apply in India or abroad.As explained by the external affairs ministry in a press release, the e-Passport is a hybrid passport that combines both paper and electronic elements. It features an embedded Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) chip and an antenna, which store and secure the holder’s data in accordance with International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) standards.Critical information printed on the data page is also stored electronically on the chip, enabling enhanced security and authentication, the ministry says. Going forward, all newly issued passports will be e-Passports, while existing non-electronic passports will remain valid until their expiry, it added.As mentioned above, any Indian citizen who is eligible for a regular passport can apply for e-passport.The process of applying for an e-passport is the same as that of applying for a regular passport. Applicants are required to first register on the official Passport Seva portal using their personal details. After completing the registration, they must fill in the online application form carefully and pay the prescribed fee through the available payment options.Once the payment is completed, applicants are required to book an appointment at a nearby Passport Seva Kendra or Post Office Passport Seva Kendra, based on their location and slot availability. On the scheduled date, the applicant must visit the selected centre in person for document verification.During the appointment, biometric details of the applicant are captured. This includes taking fingerprints and a photograph, which are used for identity verification and are later embedded securely into the e-passport’s electronic chip.After the verification process is completed and the application is cleared, the e-passport is printed with the embedded chip that stores the holder’s biometric and personal details. The finished e-passport is then dispatched and delivered to the applicant’s registered residential address through the postal system.
Article Summary: The Ministry of External Affairs rolled out e-passport service under the Passport Seva Programme (PSP V2.0) The new system aims to facilitate faster, more secure, and smooth travel for all Indian passport holders. Anyone applying for a passport will get a chip-enabled passport by default.

Article Title: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon repeats his earlier warning on AI eliminating jobs, wants employees to focus on skills like ...
Article Text:
AI must be regulated: JPMorgan CEO





Jamie Dimon, CEO of America’s largest bank, JPMorgan Chase CEO has once again warned that artificial intelligence (AI) will eliminate jobs in the long run. Speaking in an interview with Fox News’ Sunday Morning Futures, Dimon urged workers to focus on human skills such as critical thinking, emotional intelligence and communication to stay relevant in the future workforce. He said individuals should build skills that machines cannot easily copy. These include problem-solving, emotional understanding, creativity, and clear communication.Jamie Dimon said that while companies have been cautious about hiring in recent months, this slowdown is not being driven by AI. He also said he does not expect the technology to cause large job losses in the immediate future.“For the most part, AI is going to do great stuff for mankind, like tractors did, like fertilizers did, like vaccines did,” Dimon said during the interview. “You know, maybe one day we’ll be working less hard but having wonderful lives.”At the same time, Jamie Dimon stressed that AI will eventually replace some jobs and that people must prepare for this shift. Notably, this is not the first time Dimon has warned about AI eliminating jobs. He has previously warned that automation will change the nature of work. In November 2025, Dimon said AI could help people in developed countries move toward a much shorter workweek of around three-and-a-half days over the next 20 to 40 years.Dimon also said that AI must be regulated properly to limit its risks, just as earlier technologies were brought under rules to protect society. He said both governments and companies have a shared responsibility to manage the impact of AI on workers.“We—government and we the companies, society—should look at how do we phase it in a way that we don’t damage a lot of people,” he said. He pointed to past examples where factory closures hurt entire towns and said better support could have reduced the damage. “You can retrain people, relocate people, income assistance, early retirement,” he added.While warning about future job losses, Dimon also said AI is already creating new jobs in the short term. He said the growth of AI requires large investments in infrastructure, including construction work and fibre-optic networks, which will generate employment.
Article Summary: Jamie Dimon, CEO of America’s largest bank, JPMorgan Chase CEO has once again warned that artificial intelligence will eliminate jobs in the long run. Dimon urged workers to focus on human skills such as critical thinking, emotional intelligence and communication to stay relevant in the future workforce.

These relay installations are essential for maintaining low-latency connections and service reliability across India's varied geography.The company posted four specialist positions at its Bengaluru office in October, recruiting talent in payments, accounting, treasury, and tax operations as part of infrastructure expansion. Article Title: ‘If you have a womb…’: Elon Musk’s words set social media ablaze over the definition of women
Article Text:
Elon Musk’s definition of women sparks rapid spread and scientific pushback





Musk's Daughter Vivian SLAMS His 'Masculinity Expectations'; Says Her Birth Was 'A Monetary Transaction'

Public figures and the escalating battle over gender narratives









Elon Musk is once again in the headlines and at the centre of a social media storm when he posted a very forthright definition of a woman on X. The head of Tesla and SpaceX took to social media and described a woman simply as someone with a womb and this definition went viral in a matter of minutes. In no time at all, this definition had ignited a barometer of reactions on social media, with people both responding in support of Musk's comments and railing against them. The whole episode brings to light how gender has become a very divisive topic on social media, especially when such statements come from people in positions of influence. The controversy underscores platform amplification effects, cultural sensitivities, and how celebrity statements rapidly shape online discourse across diverse global audiences.Musk’s comment went straight to the point with: "If you have a womb, you’re a woman. Otherwise, you’re not." The directness and clarity of this statement were key in making it go viral on X, with people sharing screenshots, re-posts, and reactions to Musk’s comment. Those in support of Musk celebrated such a comment as an affirmation of a biological distinction, where they did not think sex stereotypes ought to be blurred in conversations in society.Musk’s response of "Seriously" to a comment in support of him further pushed all this.Critics were quick to question this claim on biological grounds. Some people brought up the case of Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome, where girls are born without a uterus or with an underdeveloped uterus. Some people observed that biology is not a simple matter of defining an organ but a whole series of factors, including chromosomes, hormones, and developmental differences. Such comments questioned the simplicity of Musk’s statement.The controversy did not arise in a vacuum, but in a sequence of statements Musk recently made concerning his transgender daughter, which have already sparked criticism for their wording. Furthermore, this latest controversy can be linked to statements by California Governor Gavin Newsom in support of trans rights, providing a political dimension to this cyber discourse. Such occurrences can be attributed to a cultural split over gender definitions. The strength of this response to Musk’s status update demonstrates just how potent outspoken leaders can be in molding and fueling public discourse.While some supporters saw this status update as a voice of clarity in a confusing debate, for others it embodied a sense of ‘othering and misunderstanding.’ Either way, this situation exemplifies how social media is becoming an increasingly central front in a series of debating-ground battles concerning all things science, culture, and ideology.
Article Summary: Elon Musk's definition of women sparks rapid spread and scientific pushback. The Tesla and SpaceX head described a woman simply as someone with a womb and this definition went viral in a matter of minutes. The whole episode brings to light how gender has become a very divisive topic on social media.

' Agentforce ' replaces two decades of cloud branding





Salesforce and Marc Benioff bets billions on AI agent technology





Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff has banished the word "cloud" from his vocabulary—a departure for the man who pioneered cloud computing in 1999 and built a quarter-trillion-dollar empire around the technology. The shift signals how dramatically the software industry's conversation has evolved in the age of artificial intelligence.Benioff revealed he completely stopped using the term after focus groups showed customers no longer want to hear about cloud technology—they want to discuss AI agents instead, Business Insider reported. The CEO avoided mentioning "cloud" entirely during his keynote address at the company's annual Dreamforce conference in October, a first in the event's history."I dropped the word cloud totally," Benioff told Business Insider in a recent interview. "We learned in focus groups customers don't talk about cloud anymore. They just want to talk about their agentic interface."The rebranding extends far beyond semantics. Salesforce has systematically renamed many of its flagship products under the "Agentforce" moniker—its AI agent software. Sales Cloud became "Agentforce Sales," Service Cloud transformed into "Agentforce Service," and Platform morphed into "Agentforce 365 Platform."Even Data Cloud, the company's data platform, was rechristened "Data 360."According to Business Insider report Benioff confirmed the company might even consider renaming Salesforce itself to Agentforce. "That would not shock me," he said when asked about the possibility.The pivot reflects Salesforce's massive bet on AI agents, autonomous software that can handle customer service, sales tasks, and other business functions traditionally performed by human workers. Token usage hit nearly 540 billion in October alone, climbing 25% month-over-month.The strategy appears central to Salesforce's ambitious target of reaching $60 billion in revenue by fiscal year 2030, up from a forecasted $41.5 billion for the current fiscal year. The company recently bolstered this vision with an $8 billion acquisition of Informatica, which builds AI tools for managing corporate data.Despite initial investor skepticism, the AI push showed positive signs in Salesforce’s recent earnings report, prompting the company to raise its revenue forecast.

Article Title: One of America’s biggest consumer tech brand Roomba maker iRobot files for bankruptcy, sold to its Chinese supplier
Article Text:
iRobot, the maker of Roomba, has filed for bankruptcy and will be acquired by its supplier, Shenzhen PICEA Robotics. This move cancels $264 million in debt, allowing iRobot to continue operations as a private company. Intense competition from Chinese firms and the collapse of an Amazon acquisition deal led to the company's downfall after 35 years.

Chinese competition and tariffs squeeze profits

Amazon deal collapse proves final blow





iRobot, the company behind the Roomba vacuum cleaner, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Sunday in Delaware court after 35 years of operation. The robotics manufacturer will be acquired by Shenzhen PICEA Robotics, its primary supplier and lender.Under the restructuring agreement, Picea will take complete ownership of the reorganized company and cancel approximately $264 million in debt, including $190 million from a 2023 loan and $74 million owed under manufacturing agreements. The company's common stock will be eliminated from exchanges, and iRobot will operate as a private entity. The deal allows iRobot to continue operations without disruption to customer support, app functionality, or supply chain relationships.Founded in 1990 by three MIT roboticists, iRobot achieved massive success after launching the Roomba in 2002, eventually selling over 50 million robots. The company went public in 2005 and reached a valuation of $3.56 billion during the pandemic in 2021. However, earnings declined steadily since then due to intensifying competition from lower-priced Chinese rivals like Ecovacs Robotics and supply chain disruptions.Despite maintaining strong market positions with 42% share in the U.S. and 65% in Japan, iRobot struggled to maintain profitability. The company generated $682 million in revenue in 2024 but faced mounting pressures from price competition and a 46% tariff on Vietnamese imports that added $23 million to costs in 2025. By its third quarter, iRobot's cash reserves had dwindled to $24.8 million with no additional capital sources available.The final blow came when Amazon's proposed $1.7 billion acquisition collapsed in January 2024 after European regulators threatened to block the deal over competition concerns. Amazon paid a $94 million breakup fee, but iRobot immediately laid off 31% of its workforce and CEO Colin Angle resigned. The company's stock plummeted more than 90% over five years, leaving it valued at just $140 million before the bankruptcy filing.
Article Summary: iRobot will be acquired by its supplier, Shenzhen PICEA Robotics. The move cancels $264 million in debt, allowing iRobot to continue operations as a private company. Intense competition from Chinese firms and the collapse of an Amazon acquisition deal led to the company's downfall after 35 years.

Following its policy to make US visas stricter, the Donald Trump administration is making the US visa-vetting system tighter. So, starting today (December 15), the US government has expanded its screening and vetting procedures for the applicants of H-1B visa program and their dependent H-4 visas. “As of December 15, the Department will expand the requirement that an online presence review be conducted for all H-1B applicants and their dependents, in addition to the students and exchange visitors already subject to this review. To facilitate this vetting, all applicants for H-1B and their dependents (H-4), F, M, and J nonimmigrant visas are instructed to adjust the privacy settings on all of their social media profiles to “public,” said the US State Department in a press release.The State Department has further added that it will use all the available information in visa screening and vetting process in order to identify the visa applicants. “We conduct thorough vetting of all visa applicants, including online presence review of all student and exchange visitor applicants in the F, M, and J nonimmigrant classifications.”According to the US Department of State, the new measures include:Officials emphasised that the changes are designed to strengthen national security while maintaining the integrity of the visa system. “Every visa adjudication is a national security decision. The United States must be vigilant during the visa issuance process to ensure that those applying for admission into the United States do not intend to harm Americans and our national interests, and that all applicants credibly establish their eligibility for the visa sought, including that they intend to engage in activities consistent with the terms for their admission. The post reminded visa applicants to disclose all social media usernames or handles they’ve used over the past five years while filling out the DS-160 visa application form. “Visa applicants are required to list all social media usernames or handles of every platform they have used from the last 5 years on the DS-160 visa application form” the post read. “Applicants certify that the information in their visa application is true and correct before they sign and submit.”The requirement is part of broader vetting procedures introduced by the US State Department this year. Article Title: Paramount to Netflix: Your 'YouTube reason' to buy Warner Brothers is like Coca-Cola justifying it can buy Pepsi because ...
Article Text:
Donald Trump Attacks $72B Netflix–WBD Deal, Demands CNN Be ‘Sold Or Included’ In Mega Merger

Why analysts not convinced with Netflix's 'YouTube reasoning'







Netflix says it must acquire Warner Bros Discovery to compete with YouTube. In fact, YouTube has become a key player in Netflix‘s plans to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery. As the streaming giant Netflix says that even if the company were to acquire Warner Bros. , it would still be behind YouTube in terms of total viewing time as measured by Nielsen. Netflix’s Co-CEO Greg Peters brought up this point while speaking at UBS’ 2025 Global Media and Communications Conference in New York last week. Peters made the statement on the same day when Paramount filed its hostile bid. “We go from 8% of viewed hours today in the United States to 9%. We’re still behind YouTube at 13%,” Peters said, referring to what would happen if the company acquired HBO and HBO Max.The reason Netflix co-CEO specifically pointed out, if Paramount acquired Warner Bros., their newly combined portion of US viewership would jump to 13.8% and that would put them above YouTube is to stress on the point that if Paramount, which accounted for 8.2% of November viewership, purchased all of Warner Bros. Discovery, it would account for 13.8% of all US viewership. That would put the combined companies ahead of both Netflix and YouTube.To sum up, Paramount buying Warner Bros. is a bigger anticompetitive threat than Netflix.“We go from 8% of viewed hours today in the United States to 9%. We’re still behind YouTube at 13%,” he said. “We think that there’s a really strong fundamentals-based case here for why regulators should approve this deal,” Peters added.In response to Netflix co-CEO's comment, Paramount Skydance CEO David Ellison, compared the statement to Coca-Cola justifying a Pepsi purchase because Budweiser also makes beverages. Speaking to CNBC’s David Faber on "Squawk on the Street", Ellison said, "I’m sorry this is like following that analogy for a second, right? Okay, that’s like saying Coke can buy Pepsi, that they’re both beverages because Budweiser is a substitute for Coke. That’s not a realistic argument. Now let’s actually look at it from the talent community, the greatest showrunners in the world. David Benioff is not going to take the next Game of Thrones to basically TikTok or to Instagram. They’re going to take it to Netflix. They’re going to take it to Amazon. They’re going to take it to Apple, they’re going to take it to HBO Max. They’re going to take it to Paramount Plus. That’s not actually how the ecosystem works. If this deal is allowed to come to pass, it is anti-competitive, and it is a horrible deal for Hollywood. And as someone who spent the last 15 years of my life producing movies and television shows, this is an industry that I love, this is an existential moment for our business, and we believe that what we are offering is better for Hollywood. It’s better for the customers and it’s pro-competitive.""And when you look at the consolidation of market share that would occur by combining Warner Bros. Discovery and Netflix, that is unprecedented market share. And so from that standpoint, we think that, that is deeply anticompetitive," he added. Talking numbers, Paramount CEO said, "We are trying to combine the number four streamer with the number five streamer. When you put Paramount and HBO Max together, you get round numbers, 200 million subscribers. That creates a streaming service that is competitive with Disney. When you put number one and number three together, you are handing Netflix unprecedented market power, which is anti-competitive in every single measure, every single metric you can measure. And we think that is bad. Again, it’s bad for the consumer. It’s bad for the creative community. This deal, if it is allowed to move forward, will actually be the death of the theatrical movie business in Hollywood. We’re sitting here today trying to save it."According to a report by Reuters, antitrust experts doubt regulators will buy Netflix argument. While Netflix insists the deal is needed to challenge Google's YouTube, which media analysis firm Nielsen ranks as America's most-watched TV distributor. However, attorneys quoted in the report say that the Justice Department is unlikely to see Netflix and YouTube as interchangeable rivals, given their different content, audiences and business models. "Netflix is trying to say it competes with YouTube because people only watch a certain amount of content a day," said Abiel Garcia, antitrust partner at Kesselman Brantly Stockinger. "That argument ultimately fails."The DOJ is not likely to view those videos as a substitute for Netflix shows and movies, experts said. While companies often seek to defend their mergers by pointing to competition from a broad universe of established and emerging players, antitrust enforcers are experienced in finding the ways that mergers quash competition in distinct sub-markets.
Article Summary: Netflix says it must acquire Warner Bros Discovery to compete with YouTube. Netflix's Co-CEO Greg Peters made the statement on the same day when Paramount filed its hostile bid. If Paramount acquired Warner Bros., their newly combined portion of US viewership would jump to 13.8% and that would put them above YouTube.

Some Ukrainians seem very angry with American chip giants Texas Instruments (TI), AMD and Intel. Dozens of Ukrainian civilians have reportedly filed a series of lawsuits in Texas this week, accusing some of the biggest US chip companies of negligently failing to track chips that evaded export curbs. According to a report in Ars Technics, those chips were ultimately used to power Russian and Iranian weapon systems, causing wrongful deaths.According to the report, their complaints alleged that for years, Texas Instruments (TI), AMD, and Intel have ignored public reporting, government warnings, and shareholder pressure to do more to track final destinations of chips and shut down shady distribution channels diverting chips to sanctioned actors in Russia and Iran.The lawsuit claims that these American chipmakers failed to prevent their products from reaching hostile regimes. “There are export lists. All that intermediaries who placed bulk online orders had to do to satisfy chip companies was check a box confirming that the shipment wouldn’t be sent to sanctioned countries," lead attorney Mikal Watts told reporters at a press conference, as reported by Kyiv Independent.The claims in this case arise under Texas tort law, which imposes a duty on companies to act with reasonable care and to prevent foreseeable harm. The factual record includes extensive evidence that the defendants also violated US export control laws designed to stop exactly this kind of diversion. The complaint lays out a consistent pattern of misconduct. Defendants sold into regions already identified as high risk. They continued doing business with distributors who had been publicly linked to sanctioned actors. The indicators of diversion were clear. They proceeded anyway.The complaint has four causes of action. The first is a negligence claim. Plaintiffs allege that the defendants had a duty under Texas law to exercise reasonable care in how they designed, implemented, and enforced compliance and export control systems. The complaint states that the companies breached that duty in several ways. They failed to conduct adequate due diligence on high-risk customers and distributors. They failed to respond to repeated government advisories and public reports showing that their products were being diverted. They allowed sales to continue into known high-risk transshipment hubs without strengthening controls. They kept working with intermediaries that had been linked to diversion activity. They failed to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable misuse of their microchips in weapons systems used against civilians. They also continued selling microprocessors and related technology, directly or indirectly, into channels that supplied China, Russia, and Iran, which ultimately armed the military drones used against Ukrainian civilians.The complaint then alleges negligence per se. Plaintiffs assert that the defendants violated U.S. export control laws, sanctions regulations, and Executive Orders entered by Presidents Obama, Trump, and Biden that bar the diversion of sensitive microelectronics to hostile actors. These laws exist to prevent U.S. technology from reaching foreign weapons programs and to protect civilians from the harm that follows when those safeguards are ignored. Because the defendants violated these rules, the complaint treats their conduct as automatically negligent and a proximate cause of the injuries at issue.Plaintiffs also bring a claim for gross negligence. They allege that the companies had actual knowledge of an extreme degree of risk. The harm was predictable. Public reporting showed their chips repeatedly appearing in Russian and Iranian weapons systems. Congressional testimony, industry analysis, and government warnings made the threat plain. Despite this information, the defendants allegedly failed to adopt effective compliance measures and continued their existing sales practices with full awareness of the potential consequences.The complaint next sets out wrongful death claims. Families who lost loved ones in drone and missile attacks allege that defendants’ negligent and grossly negligent conduct was a direct and proximate cause of those deaths. These plaintiffs seek damages for the loss of companionship, mental anguish, and other harms recognized under the Texas Wrongful Death statute.Finally, the complaint includes survival claims. Plaintiffs assert that the decedents suffered physical pain, mental anguish, property loss, and medical expenses before death. Their estates seek recovery for those losses, as well as funeral expenses. Because the complaint alleges that the defendants acted with gross negligence, both the wrongful death and survival claims seek exemplary damages as permitted by Texas law. Exemplary damages are a category of damages intended to punish especially wrongful conduct and to deter similar conduct in the future.
